Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at the International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports student travel for select students participating in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the Eighteenth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS), Montreal, Canada, May 13-17, 2019. This is the premier international conference for researchers in agents and multi-agent systems (MAS) across a fully international research community. This consortium is oriented on research and career development for students who have identified their PhD topics and are just embarking on that independent research. The central activities for the DMC include opportunities for students to present and discuss their work with their peers; interaction with an identified group of senior researchers for advice on Ph.D. research, a career panel to discuss career choices in industry and academia, small group activities led by assigned mentors, and a great deal of opportunity for interactions with the international research community in AAMAS, which might lead to future collaborative activity. In addition, the DMC includes a tutorial program with full-day and half-day tutorials that will provide detailed overviews of specific subfields by leading researchers in the field.

Sponsoring student travel to AAMAS conveys many benefits beyond the DMC program. The sponsored students have full access to a well-developed AAMAS workshop and conference program covering a diverse range of research areas in this community. This is an opportunity for students to engage in discussion with scientists from around the world and to explore new research directions and topics. AAMAS is the major international conference that will figure prominently in the research careers of students who remain involved in agents and MAS. Students gain valuable research insights from the exchange of technical ideas in this broader venue. In the process, they make valuable connections with potential collaborators from around the world. As intelligent software and embodies systems become more prevalent, it is clear that advances in intelligent agent technology will have significant impact in virtually any domain imaginable, including such national priorities as health and well-being, e-commerce, and national defense.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 AAMAS Doctoral Consortium (DC) brought together 22 early career researchers and additional participants from the AAMAS main conference to share emerging research, build mentoring and advising relationships, and expand the network of a diverse set of scholars. Participants represented  11 countries, including the United States, Brazil, Sweden, Scotland, Singapore, Australia, Germany, France, Portugal, India, and Canada. Participation was supported for nine researchers from the US, including four women. The DC participants presented their ongoing research, and engaged with four senior researched on a panel. The panel included Noa Agmon, Edith Elkind, Matt Taylor, and Neil Yorke-Smith.

 

DC participants also participated in small group exercise in which they discussed the following prompt:

We all have seen the various computer companies adds at TV on how artificial Intelligence can make society better by protecting the environment and better feeding the planet. Or helping one getting healthier by better being in charge of its fitness routine. Or how the various assistants can help sofa-bound humans with mundane day to day choices. Recently, in an interview with the British writer Ian McEwan it was even discussed at length the issue of whether parents should teach their children to say thank you and please to such assistants. The artificial intelligence empowered technologies are undoubtedly already a part of our life. But where is this all heading to? Disastrous paradigm change end of the world scenarios with killer robots taking over? Or despite the marketing efforts, the changes are really very incremental with no meaningful impact? In this discussion session we urge you to think on how such technologies could impact your life in the years to come. Have a think about the most common misunderstandings of what artificial intelligence is and what it can really achieve. Consider deployment of artificial intelligence enabled computer systems and its influence on people, communities and society. What are the challenges it faces? Does it have the potential to overcome them? What could be a measure of success for artificial intelligence?

Participants in discussion sessions explored potential AI applications with potential positive impacts, current societal problems of interest, possible approaches to addressing the problems and the challenges of their proposed approaches for practical deployment and/or broad public adoption.
